You strive to become the most prestigious family. But beware! Those pesky Iberians of Baitolo can stil give Romans a nasty surprise. And take care of the development of the rival Municipium of Barcino.

Name: Egyptian Flood
Description:
Egyptian Flood, a card game for 2-6 players featuring city building and destroying.

Designed and ideas by: Benjamin Sperling (Gurken Games), James Casey, Byron Grimes, Erik Lechak, Craig Somerton, August Larson, Jay LaFountain.

Instructions:
You need these items to play:
10 Farm cards, 10 Floods, 7 Settlements, 6 Kingdoms, 5 Pyramids, 6 Soldiers, 7 Riches, 4 Anubises, 4 Sandstorms, 5 Harvests.
Some kind of coins for gold, different color tokens for each player, and another type of token to represent damage to buildings (solider damage and flood damage).

The deck of cards should be shuffled and each player is dealt four cards from the central deck.  Choose one player to go first and have each player chooses his or her color.  All players take 3 gold from the bank.

The first player draws one card and plays a card from their hand.  That player does what the card says, then the turn ends and the next player begins their turn.

The game ends when no one is able to play any further cards.

Winning: 
Each player earns 1 victory point for each gold they have plus 2 victory points for each pyramid they control.  The highest total wins the game.

I hope you enjoy this game.  It was a collaborative effort of the above designers and idea people.

Name: Sengoku
Description:
From the publisher web page:

Compete against up to three other players as a daimyo (Japanese for 'leader') in 16th century Japan during the Sengoku Period (Japanese for 'Warring States'). Build a robust economy, fortify your castle, battle for control of other fiefdoms, and decorate your palace to achieve victory and be declared Emperor over all of Japan.

Name: The War of the Empires 1914-1918
Description:
The War of the Empires 1914-1918 is a turn-based board-wargame for up to 6 players, with two confronted sides: Central Powers vs Entente (the number of players on each side doesn't need to be equal). The number of army units of every country in the game is proportional to the real military powers at the begining of the First World War. This is Sven Nemet's game before he become a boardgame geek (it was made in 1997). The duration of the game can be up to 4 hours, but there are also shorter versions, for example Russian empire against Austria-Hungary for 2 players (cca. 45 minutes).
Die is used for fighting, but bonuses can be added to the number rolled on die if you: have a double number of units in a fight, have surrounded your enemy, have modernized your units, have used a tactical advantage card…
You can buy infantry, ships, planes, harbours... 
Both sides draw event cards in every round – Russian winter, famine, the possibility to get some neutral country to fight on your side, American intervention etc.
There is the factor of luck in the game, but hey, it adds to the excitement!

Go and let the best one win!

Name: Frontline General: San Pietro Infine
Description:
Entirely tactical, this wargame covers the WWII Battle of San Pietro in its entirety through a series of challenging scenarios.  New US, German, and Italian units represent the full historic strength of the fighting forces that struggled for control of the mountains Sambúcaro, Lungo, and Rotondo, and the small village of San Pietro Infine located in the foothills of Monte Sambúcaro.

Collins Epic Wargames is working with artist Mark Mahaffey to produce a functional and beautiful large, mounted 32"x27" full color map at a scale of 1"=500'.  Each 1.2" hex represents 200 yards with platoons and sections as the basic maneuver units.  All terrain modifiers are conveniently printed right in the hex to provide even more terrain representation flexibility and ease of reference during the game.  Large 7/8" counters are easy to read and pair one for one with the game’s Unit Cards - Cards that handle all of the important combat and maneuver stats, track earned experience, and provide a step-loss reduction to easily track damage.
